Posts.Content: May 21, 2010 06:44PM gcpommom wrote: I had dose dense AC, and was supposed to have dose dense Taxol, but my onc switched it to weekly Taxol since I had alot of problems with side effects on the AC, and he said the weekly would be easier on me since I "don't metabolize medicines well"....riiight, I'd like to see how he metabolizes chemo, lol.  I don't believe that all chemo meds have the option to be dose dense or not, but Taxol is one that you can do either weekly or biweekly (or every 3 weeks, if they're still doing that)
Posts.Title: Question about "Dose Dense" in_cognito my2boys

Posts.Content: Apr 3, 2009 07:20PM gcpommom wrote: Brian and Snowflake, I had the same thing happen to me about 3 weeks ago.  I had already done 3 chemo treatments, and then had pain in my rib area.  Went to ER, and they found a pulmonary embolism.  I was only in the hospital for one night, got shots in my tummy for a couple of weeks while they started me on coumadin.  I will have to take it for 6 months. Having cancer does increase your risk for blood clots.  Chemo increases the risk a bit more.  However, now that she will be on blood thinners, she should be ok.  I took a short break from my chemo, and have since resumed treatments. If you have any questions feel free to pm me.  I have done a lot of research over the last week, since the doctors couldn't answer a lot of my questions about my PE.  I know how scared she must be right now, I know I was. Judy
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed - what should we look for in a doctor? Snowflake70 LindaYO

Posts.Content: Apr 17, 2009 09:03PM gcpommom wrote: I had no port either, and never had any problems getting AC through the veins.  I am now getting my Taxol, and my veins are doing ok.  I do get a little tired of getting poked each week, first for bloodwork, then for the IV for tx.  But it seems like using the veins is doable. Good luck to you on your tx's!
Posts.Title: No Port, First Chemo, On With The Show! lizardbreath LRM216

Posts.Content: Jan 10, 2009 03:13AM gcpommom wrote: Well, I had my surgery yesterday at 9am.  I was discharged at 5:30-6pm.  I was given the option to stay overnight, but I just wanted to come home and see my son.  I'm glad I did, it has been nice to lay in bed, my kids coming and going and resting comfortably.  They gave me a camisole, but for the first couple of weeks, I also have to wear this tube top "corset", which is very tight and is giving me a rash where the ruffle lays along the top/bottom.  While it is very cute, purple with flowers, looks like an actual tube top (but has rigid plastic where it velcros shut), I am not happy with all the itching. They did not end up taking any muscle as they thought they would, but had to take some extra skin, due to fact that tumor was high up on breast and very close to both muscle and skin.  That makes me nervous, as I have no other info on what that could mean.  She took 6 lymph nodes instead of just the 2, and told my DH that she had to remove extras in order to get to the ones that were targeted during the SNB. Anyway, chest is sore, tight, drains doing ok.  I can walk around a bit.  The dry mouth was the pits, but that is getting better this morning.  I have asthma, and the pain killers/tightness are contributing to a shortness of breath, so I have only slept in short bursts of a couple of hours at a time.  I hope to get off the narcotics and switch to regular tylenol within a few days; drugs that make me feel dopey also mess with my breathing, and that is an extra stress I do not need right now.  They gave me something called Norco, which basically looks to be Vicadin from what I've read. All in all, I am doing ok, glad to be home.  I know there were others having surgery this week, and I hope you all are doing well.  Judy B.
Posts.Title: January Mastectomy crusader1 bettelou68

Posts.Content: Jan 2, 2009 08:23PM - edited Jan 2, 2009 09:37PM by gcpommom
Posts.Title: January Mastectomy crusader1 bettelou68

Posts.Content: Oct 10, 2009 08:31PM gcpommom wrote: Hannah, I saw you on Good Morning America this week...you look wonderful!  I hope your upcoming surgery goes smoothly for you, and enjoy those American Girl dolls...lucky!!! LOL
Posts.Title: HELP! 10 year old with bc cjsocal Mary-Lou

Posts.Content: Dec 21, 2008 07:55PM - edited Dec 21, 2008 08:06PM by gcpommom I am having a bilateral mastectomy on Jan. 9th.  Can't put the expanders in right away since they have to remove some muscle to get clear margins.  Now I have to wait til after chemo to do that. I am very nervous about how my chest will feel after all of this; I have asthma, and any tightness (like tight tops or bras) make me really uncomfortable (kinda claustrophobic).  So I am worried about that aspect.  I can't even wear t-shirts that go to the neck because it feels suffocating to me.   I had DCIS in 2004, so I have done alot of research over the years, and understand most of the terminology (although there are some new ones, like 'Oncotype', that I don't remember from 2004). One thing I plan to get that isn't on the list--at least not that I've noticed--is one of those grabber things, so I can grab things that are overhead when no one is around to help me out.  Has anyone used those?  My MIL suggested it. Judy B.
Posts.Title: January Mastectomy crusader1 bettelou68

Posts.Content: May 28, 2009 05:45AM gcpommom wrote: I am not done with chemo yet, but have not had much problem with neuropathy yet.  My legs often feel weak, and heavy, especially at the knees, so I am putting my coordination problems down to that for now.  I am able to do the closed-eye test so I guess it's just the leg/knee muscles causing my problems.
Posts.Title: Anyone else have balance problems long after finishing chemo? otter Cif

Posts.Content: gcpommom wrote: I just received my biopsy results this morning, invasive BC, almost 5 years after having DCIS in other breast. Anyway, I have a question for those with children.  When should I tell my 11 year old?  Should I wait until I find out exactly what my treatment will entail, or just tell him now?  I am afraid that I will be too emotional right now to calmly tell him.  But then again, I'm afraid that he already suspects something is going on, and don't know what to do.  He's my baby, we're very close. Judy B. The friend who holds your hand and says the wrong thing is made of dearer stuff than the one who stays away. Diagnosis: 3/12/2004, DCIS, Dx 12/4/2008, IDC, 2cm, Stage IIA, Grade 3, 0/6 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed, question re: children, please guide me... gcpommom Rarity

Posts.Content: Dec 8, 2008 12:29AM gcpommom wrote: Wow, thank you all for all of the replies, what wonderful advice. I told my son on Friday afternoon, "mommy has breast cancer".  I discussed how I don't know much yet, which I don't, but that I would have surgery, and that I may need chemo.  He didn't know what that was, so I explained it a bit.  He did ok, actually, no tears, no questions.  I am still worried about what he is thinking, but told him he really needs to come to me any time to talk or cry or share his feelings.  He gave me a really long hug, and I thought for a moment that the tears were going to come, but they didn't.  I really hope he will eventually talk about his fears, I don't want him to keep it all inside. So this weekend, we rented movies and video games, and put up our Christmas tree, and had a really nice weekend in spite of it all.   I think that trying to keep things as normal as possible is important right now, although I don't know how long that will be possible. Being a substitute teacher in our district, I had already let his teacher know that I was getting the biopsy (my son was already a bit moody in class as his sister is also very ill, and in and out of the hospital often).  So since I had to explain that to his teacher, I also told her about myself.  I sent a note to her on Friday letting her know my diagnosis, asking her to call me anytime to let me know how he is doing in school. Thank you for your help and for sharing your experiences.  It was very helpful to me.  Judy B.
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed, question re: children, please guide me... gcpommom Rarity

Posts.Content: Nov 25, 2009 11:01AM gcpommom wrote: JudyN: I was also about 5 months out when they came out again (now), but they didn't all fall out, and they are coming back in pretty quickly now.  the eyebrows are still a bit thin though.  And I just noticed after my shower today that even the leg hair has fallen out in blotches here and there.  Weird Chelev:  I absolutely love your hair.  I want to get the chemical straightening done, too, but wasn't sure if it was too soon.  Your's looks really good.  Everyone looks great, I love looking at the pics, and trying to get ideas on what to do with this hair, lol.  Right now I am just using a straightening serum....it's not bad, and at least works in the front, not so much on the back. Judy B.

Judy

Posts.Content: Jan 19, 2010 06:30PM gcpommom wrote: Thank you for the compliments. JudyNaomi, you look very pretty in your avatar : )  Nodapearl, I  use gel and hairspray.  I don't like that I have "crunchy" hair, lol, but without the gel, it is too frizzy.  I started taking Biotin in late Novemeber, and it has really seemed to make a difference, I had a large amount of hair growth in the last 2 months.
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Apr 12, 2010 08:45AM gcpommom wrote: Dublin:  I'm glad I helped : )  I remember being where you are now, hang in there, there is a light at the end of the tunnel!!
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Dec 5, 2008 09:24AM gcpommom wrote: CMB:  thank you, I thought about a book, but wasn't sure if they would be too young for him, as you mentioned.  I am telling him today, so here goes I guess.  He knows that one of my friends was just diagnosed with lung cancer, and I need to be sure to tell him that that is very different from breast cancer, because he has overheard conversations about her prognosis.  I think that is what will pop into his head first, since it is the first person he knows who has cancer, and he will associate that with mine.  I grew up with a mother who always had one  health problem after another....kidney stones, blood clots, diabetes, thyroid cancer, heart attack.....but she was always amazingly strong and level-headed and calm about it each time.  I know now that she was probably just as scared inside as I am, but that we must appear outwardly strong for our children.  So that is what I plan to do.  Not to be deceiving, but to be strong and confident I guess.  Of course, I'm sure I'll cry in front of him at some point during the next few months (I never saw my mother cry, but I am much more emotional, or maybe she just cried in private). He is coming home at lunchtime, I am pulling him out of school for the afternoon so we can have time together to talk.  Wish me luck.  I'm most scared of this, more than anything else.

This was my head in 6/15, 2 weeks PFC: Then on 7/8/09, 5 weeks PFC, had now lost eyebrows/lashes:  Then today, 7/28/09, 8 weeks PFC, after coloring it yesterday (couldn't stand the white hair) I just used my regular permanent color, *note eyebrows/lashes are back, yay!:  The gray hair didn't all cover with the color.....will try something darker next time, this color is a mix of light and medium blonde I always used.  It now looks kind of tan in color. Posts.Content: Sep 16, 2009 07:57PM gcpommom wrote: Hi gals.. I haven't posted here in a bit, so thought I'd post a pic of my hair, now 15 wks PFC.  It seems to get thicker, but not much longer, most of it looks to be about 3/4 inches now, some is longer, some is shorter.  It appears that it may start curling.  when I was younger, right up until the last 5 years or so, I had pin straight, thick hair.  Once it started graying, it started waving....so I may just be seeing that wave, I hope. for those of you trying to avoid the Gerber baby thing, the way I deal with it is this:  when it is wet, comb it all straight forward, pressing it down to your head.  After it dries a bit (not totally), add some gel and move it where you want it.  I also use John Frita's Sheer Blonde hair pomade (sp)?, it adds some blonde shimmer to it (but it's sticky stuff) You all look wonderful, by the way, and I can't wait for my hair to grow longer.....I go back to work subbing this week, and am nervous about how the students will react to my hair.  But I really have no desire to stick a wig on my head again, I'm past that! One more thing to add, I found the easiest way to post a pic is after you upload it to photobucket, click on the pic (so it comes up full size), then right click on that pic, copy and paste right into your message on bc.org.
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: gcpommom wrote: They are moving pretty quickly, really.  I had a chest xray, blood work, MRI and bone scan in the last two days.  I am very scared of these tests, I just keep having a bad feeling, since they say my cancer is aggressive. I have an appt on Monday to meet with my team (at a different hospital).  I am afraid to hear the results, since everything else I've found out was such a shock to me.  I guess I'm just expecting the worst. The friend who holds your hand and says the wrong thing is made of dearer stuff than the one who stays away. Posts.Content: Dec 11, 2008 11:22PM gcpommom wrote: Thank you, both, so much.  It has been very hard.  I felt strong until these tests this week, then felt like I was just totally doomed.  It surprised me. I did get the results of one test today--the chest xray.  It was clear!!!  I was so happy, I cried.  I read that with metaplastic bc, it tends to spread to the lungs easily, so I was very relieved.  I feel a bit stronger again with this news, like I'll be ok.  I could probably get the rest of the results tomorrow, but part of me wants to just wait til MOnday, to enjoy this one piece of good news this weekend.  I meet with my team of drs on Monday for the first time.
Posts.Title: Had a bunch of tests done... gcpommom gcpommom

Posts.Content: Oct 10, 2010 03:39AM gcpommom wrote: I am a teacher, but was only subbing/tutoring when I started chemo.  I've seen many teachers on here who worked through chemo.  However, that being said, there was no way I could have worked full time during chemo.  As it was, I didn't even sub or tutor, I was too sick.  So I guess there is no real way to know for sure; everyone has a different chemo experience. Not trying to worry you, just wanted to tell my experience.  Like I said, I've seen lots of teachers here who worked during chemo, so hopefully you will have an easier time than I did

Any advice?  They haven't actually asked me yet, but I want to be ready if they do.  This job would most likely run til the end of the school year.  No one at the school knows about my diagnosis yet, and I really didn't plan on telling them. The friend who holds your hand and says the wrong thing is made of dearer stuff than the one who stays away. Posts.Content: Dec 21, 2008 11:20PM gcpommom wrote: Thank you for the replies.  Jess:  I, too, had heard about doing Chemo so that your 'bad' days fall on the weekend; but I work every Mon, Wed, Thurs. and Sat., and will not have a weekend during which I can recoup.  So that worries me a bit. Denise:  I am glad to hear that you are doing ok with your tx.  I hope I can do as well.  I do have a pretty good immune system, so that might help with all the little kid germs! I have no idea what my chemo tx will entail; I meet with the Onc. after my surgery in January.  I am interested to hear what he has to say.  I had read that some drs. are treating metaplastic bc with the same chemo tx they give for lung cancer, but my surgeon says that they usually follow the usual tx as they do for IDC at my hospital (whatever that may be). Judy B.
Posts.Title: Any teachers out there? Need advice... gcpommom wellthy

Posts.Content: Nov 23, 2008 03:47PM gcpommom wrote: Hi Dorothy. Yes, I agree, the wire locaters did hurt alot, I wasn't expecting it either. My scar was also about 3 1/2-4", but my calc's were located right against my chest wall, so I guess they had to go deep to get to them.  I am 'missing' about 1/3 of that breast now.  It did seem a bit much for such a small area of calcs, it was under 1cm.  To make matters worse, they didn't get it all the first time, and I was back in a week later for more surgery.  He put it down as a 'partial mastectomy' he said so I could get implants through my insurance.  Not at all what I was expecting, though.  That was in 2004, I am still without implant, too chicken.  since it was the outer side of my breast, you can't tell when I'm wearing a bathing suit, etc.
Posts.Title: ALSO Waiting for Test Results Dorothy_2008 Dorothy_2008

Posts.Content: Jul 7, 2009 02:50PM gcpommom wrote: I also am trip neg, and had AC followed by Taxol.  I was nervous about it, but it was easier than the AC in so many ways.  No nausea, no breathing/heart racing problems, no total exhaustion.    I have read recently on these boards that Taxol is not always helpful for er+ women, but is for er- women, so I am glad I took it.  (However, I do not know the specifics on that statement, but believe it is based on a study) That being said, though, I did have my problems while on it, but all in all it was much better than the AC.  I was able to do things again, to get off the couch go shopping, clean, cook, eat.  Around the 7th tx is when the tingling/numbness set in, and we stopped tx at #9.  I didn't have alot of problem with body pains/aches until near the end, and after finishing tx.  I do feel like an old lady when I get up after sitting for a while, very stiff and achy.  My onc says this will go away in time.  Oh, and I lost one toenail, but it didn't hurt at all, it just looks weird. It has been a month now since I finished, and besides feeling achy in my legs and hands, and being very tired, I am ok.  The numbness is going away....I do wish I had more energy, but I would think even with just the AC, one would still be fatigued after finishing tx. Good luck with your decision.
Posts.Title: Taxol ~ is it a MUST after AC? Kitley ddlatt

Posts.Content: Dec 11, 2008 11:34PM gcpommom wrote: Ladyjane- I was just reading the book they sent me from the hospital.  It says that I can't even drive until the drains are out, which could be 1-3 weeks?!  No lifting over 10 lbs for 8 weeks after surgery?!  Wow.  I had no idea.  Currently, I sub in the elementary schools, usually grades K-3.  My tutoring job, which is with a small company with 6 locations in MI, is different, because there I teach 5th - 9th grade ELA.  It isn't one-on-one, but rather small group tutoring.  I also manage one location.  I only work part time, about 8-12 hours a week here. I had rads last time in 2004, and remember that I would start out ok at the beginning of the week, but was exhausted by the end of each week, usually napping often over the weekends.  The fatigue was really my only symptom from rads.  I've never had chemo before. I haven't had an actual offer yet, so maybe they won't call me after all.  Which would probably be for the best, because I don't think I could accept the long-term subbing position now that I know more about the recovery time for surgery.
Posts.Title: Any teachers out there? Need advice... gcpommom wellthy

Posts.Content: Dec 16, 2008 09:27AM gcpommom wrote: Hi Jane  I agree with you about the long journey through this.  I had my appt. yesterday, and surgery will be on 1/9.  But they can't do immediate reconstruction since they will have to remove some of my chest muscle to get good margins.  So now I can't have my recon. started until after chemo, probably around June.  I was so bummed out, that means 2 more surgeries to complete recon.  And if they add rads, it will be even longer, almost a year in the process.  My new bc is not a reoccurence, since it is in the opposite breast; it is a new primary, I guess.  I had DCIS in 2004, calcifications, no lump. We are alot alike-I celebrate my 25th wedding anniversary next June, have three kids:  22 and 19 yr old daughters, 11 yr old son.  I was never offered the long term job, which is just as well; I'd rather not have to turn it down or tell them what is going on with me.  When the next one comes along, I want them to call me, so the less they know, the better. It's funny you mention your dog; we have 4 dogs, but our oldest dog has been stalking me for months!  He never used to do that, and it is almost creepy.  They say that dogs can sense cancer, and I wonder if he knew all along.  If I pace the floor, he follows my every step.  If I go to bed, he lays outside my door (no carpet there, either).  He just sits at my feet while I'm at my desk.  This from a dog that hardly knew I existed a year ago.  Strange.
Posts.Title: Any teachers out there? Need advice... gcpommom wellthy

Posts.Content: Jun 6, 2009 08:53AM gcpommom wrote: Jose:  I'm sorry to hear about your girlfriend.  I had asthma going into my treatments, but my breathing got worse during my AC tx's.  I don't think it was the same exact thing your girlfriend is going through, but it definitely got bad.  I couldn't walk across the room. I think she needs to get to the pulmonary doc and they can give her some meds to help.  Having the panic attacks is something I have been through very often in the past....when my breathing gets bad, in addition to my asthma spray, I sometimes take Xanax, which relaxes me and helps my breathing...and will also help with panic.  Let us know what the doc says.  Is her appt soon?  Maybe a nebulizer would be a good thing to have at home.  Good luck to you both Hugs Judy
Posts.Title: PLEASE HELP!! Lung/Breathing Problems newmex1598 gcpommom

Posts.Content: Apr 18, 2010 03:22AM gcpommom wrote: I experienced something very similar after chemo.  Both my hands/wrists would hurt so bad, and be a weird combination of painful/numb/tingly every single morning, would wake me up throughout the night.  Thought I had developed carpal tunnel (but now think it was probably neuropathy), so  I wore wrist support braces every night trying to keep my wrists straight.  Then after a few weeks, it just went away although I still get stiffness in my hands every morning   My left hand swells slightly, but I think that is mild lymphedema since it is my lymph node side. My onc also sent me for the neck MRI, it was fine.  I think it was from the Taxol, which caused me to have so much joint pain all over for months after chemo.  Now 10 months out, I still get stiff ankles/legs if I sit too long, but nothing like it used to be.
Posts.Title: Joint pain following chemotherapy MaryNY MaryNY

Posts.Content: Mar 8, 2013 07:05AM gcpommom wrote: I found a mid-kini at Penney's last year...it already had 'pockets' which contained those thin foam modesty cups, so I took those out and put in my foam forms...the foam is light and does not weigh the top down.  They do hold water, but I just give my forms a good hard press when drying off with the towel and they are fine :)  The top is cut straight across the top, and the fringe adds a bit of camoflauge, then I adjust the straps to make it sit high enough.  Here is the top:
Posts.Title: Finding a bikini to wear after my mastectomy. Dawn444 exbrnxgrl

Posts.Content: Jun 4, 2009 03:46AM gcpommom wrote: When I was on AC, I could eat very little..... I found that I ate scrambled eggs with toast (which I usually hated), colby-jack cheese on triscuit crackers, chocolate shakes, carnation instant breakfast.  That's about all I ate for those bad days. Now on Taxol and most everything tastes fine again.  Good luck, and just experiment....something you used to hate the taste of might taste ok now.
Posts.Title: Food Suggestions - Please mln8428 nelia48

Posts.Content: May 3, 2010 03:56PM gcpommom wrote: I was 46 when I started chemo last year, had no period for 13 months, and it just started up again yesterday after spotting for 4 or 5 days, and lots of cramps.  I just had a normal pap about 2 months ago, my onc thinks my period is just returning.  I read about one woman who went 6 years before it came back, she was our age as well.  I did not have tamoxifen, don't know if that would've kept your periods at bay longer???  Are you having cramps?

Posts.Title: please help sueps barbe1958

Posts.Content: Jun 13, 2009 11:03PM gcpommom wrote: I had a similar situation.....after 3 AC tx's, I got a clot in my lung....I'm on coumadin now, too.  I couldn't finish my AC because my side effects were so bad.  I was then supposed to get DD Taxol, but since I had such a rough time with the DD AC, my doctor changed my Taxol to weekly.  It is a lower dose, and I must say the side effects were much more manageable than the AC.  No nausea, no feeling sick all the time.  I have been able to do much more while on the weekly taxol, such as cleaning, cooking, eating, etc. Maybe you should try the weekly instead of the DD.  See how it goes.
Posts.Title: I'm ready to just say no NAZSusan Seabee
